page.title: 11Nunraw Mansion
page.content: Restored last century, it exemplifies Scottish baronial revival architecture Considered to be "Ravenswood" in Scotts," Bride of Lammermoor", it presently serves as the Abbey guest house. Visitors and staying guests are legion. Comfortable quarters are avilable for beggars, all our welcome. Since conferences are also catered for, it is a constant hive of activity. By courtesy of the community, the village hold their annual Christmas party there. Of great historic interest is the chapel's 17 painted ceilings, the shields of mediaeval monachs still faintly discernable. On a balcony pulpit a fox is sculpted in monks clothing, preaching to geese. Nearby is a 16 circular dovecot. Nunraw (Nun's Row) had belonged to cistercian nuns in the 12th century.
